trial_identification.studytitle: A study to compare the effectiveness and safety of an oral low dose and megadose of cholecalciferol treatment in participants with vitamin D deficiency - a real-life comparison pilot study.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A study to compare the effectiveness and safety of an oral low dose and a megadose vitamin D treatment regimens - a real-life comparison pilot study.

interventions.interventions: The intervention will be oral 50,000 IU cholecalciferol daily for 10 days and then weekly for 3 months.
interventions.comparator: The active control will be oral 1000 IU cholecalciferol tablets at a dose of four per day for one month and then one a day for 3 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Normalisation of serum 25(0H) concentrations to > 50 nmol/L

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Safety parameters - serum and urine calcium concentrations.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Serum calcium concentrations will be measured at 10 days and 3 months. 24-hour urine calcium concentrations will be measured at 3 months.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Serum 25(0H) concentration < 50 nmol/L and ability to consent to trial participation.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Inability to either give informed consent or complete the three month study, primary or tertiary hyperparathyroidism or other causes of hypercalcaemia.

trial_design.concealment: Patients will be randomised to either high or low dose treatment groups and stratified according to baseline 25(0H)D concentration. Allocation concealment will be achieved by the use of central randomisation by another person using a computer generated table
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table created by a computer software programme. Patients will be randomised to either high or low dose treatment groups and stratified according to baseline 25(0H)D concentration.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study will compare the effectiveness and safety of an oral low dose and a megadose vitamin D treatment regimen - it will be a real-life dose comparison study. This intervention study will have an active control group. The intervention will be oral 50,000 IU cholecalciferol daily for 10 days and then weekly for 3 months. The active comparator will be lower dose oral 1000 IU cholecalciferol tablets at a dose of four per day for one month and then one a day for 3 months. The outcome will be the numbers of subjects in each group achieving an optimal serum vitamin D level at 3 months. Safety measures will also be studied.
